Award.AbstractNarration:
The project uses the resources of the UC Davis Department of Mathematics to attract more US citizens to careers in the mathematical sciences, with special attention paid to women and underrepresented groups. The main tool for this is the Research Focus Group (RFG), a construct created in the prior VIGRE grant, which has been wildly successful. An RFG is a group of faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students, who collaborate in a year-long intense exploration of a particular research area. Through RFG activities, members are exposed to cutting-edge research, and they participate in all its aspects: exploration, discovery, leadership, exposition, and lecturing. In particular, graduate students develop strong communication skills, both written and verbal. Every year, four RFGs are selected and funded.

In addition to the RFGs are activities new to this project: A Mini-Grant Program through which students can apply not just for summer stipends but for conference travel funds, or even to organize workshops, to run outreach activities, or to host visiting mathematicians. Writing a mini-grant is not only a valuable challenge that forces the students to plan and organize a research project, but it also unleashes the creativity of the graduate students and postdocs.

Mathematics majors are recruited aggressively using several tools: The EXPLORE Math program is an outreach program for high school and undergraduate students that was created by VIGRE graduate students. The project supports local student organizations, Math Club and Math Cafe, to promote peer-based recruitment and retention of mathematics majors. Mathematics fairs for senior high school students are held in geographic proximity (which includes large communities of underrepresented minorities) to attract incoming freshmen to major in math and promote career paths that use mathematics. VIGRE-funded students and postdocs are required to participate in at least two of the many outreach activities.

The increased focus on particular research areas leads to increased research productivity among students and postdocs. It may also lead to new developments and results obtained by RFG participants (e.g., theses, publications, and lecture notes). Attending conferences increases the exposure of graduate students to new ideas and to the dissemination of research.

The impact on creating a larger and better group of U.S. citizens and permanent residents working in mathematics will be significant. The project directly affects the surrounding geographic area of Northern and Central California. In the recruitment plan special attention is given to attracting and retaining minorities currently underrepresented in mathematics but abundant in this geographic area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics is the language of science and technology. Mathematics is also beautiful, elegant, and deep. Yet many young Americans today do not care about mathematics. We confront a contradiction; mathematical training is the door to the future economy and high-tech career options, mathematical knowledge is essential to modern society, yet most students do not consider mathematics for their future. This could be a critical issue in future of the nation.

The VIGRE NSF grant was a 5-year-long award received by UC Davis Math department in 2007. Its key goal was to attract more US citizens to careers in the mathematical sciences, with special attention paid to women and underrepresented groups. This general goal was broken into three concrete sub-goals:


1. To increase the quality and quantity of our graduate students and postdoctoral trainees, and to promote depth and breadth in their research education; building a strong and broad preparation for the careers they choose, whether academic or non-academic.


2. To recruit larger numbers of undergraduate students for our mathematics majors, in particular, women and underrepresented minorities, and to impress on all students the great utility of mathematical tools and the many job opportunities a degree in mathematics offers to people.

3. To reach out to the public to explain why mathematics is fundamental in modern society and can boost the economy.

Locally, VIGRE funded 13 graduate year-long fellowships, 3 postdoctoral positions, and up to 30 Research Experiences for Undergraduate stipends per year. With these resources UC Davis was able to do positive changes.  The main vehicle for achieving all the goals we mentioned was the Research Focus Groups (RFGs). An RFG is a group of faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students, who collaborate in a year-long intense exploration of a particular research area. Through RFG activities,members were exposed to cutting-edge research, and they participate inall its aspects: exploration, discovery, leadership, exposition,writing, and lecturing. In particular, graduate students developed very strong communication skills, both written and verbal because they had plenty of practice. It is important to note that RFG's included undergraduate students.

In addition to the RFGs we had other somewhat independent activities:

0) We had a number of Fellowships and Summer Fellowships. The regularacademic year fellowships were assigned to students of the best performance as judged by the graduate program committee and the VIGRE PIs, and the Summer fellowships required students to write a proposal asking for summer support.


1) We had a Mini-Grant Program through which students could apply for travel support to conferences, scientific meetings,  money to carry on special events such as hosting special speakers, organizing a mini-conference, buying special software or equipment, or any other creative intelectual endeavor.

2) The EXPLORE Math program is an outreach program for high school andundergraduate students that was created by VIGRE graduate students. It continues to run and enrolls high-school students in cities near Davis in many activities such as Math circles and competitions. Many high-school students make use of this opportunity.

3) We also supported our local student organizations, Math Club and Math Cafe, to promote peer-based training, recruitment and retention of mathematics majors.

4) The research experience for undergraduates was also a very important activity. Each year between 45-60 undergraduate students applied to be part of a research project. An average of 30 undergrads were supported with fellowships from VIGRE with typically 10 more supported by individual grants. We also had a number of students each year who participated without fellowships.
